title: Comfort & Exploration
description: Explore your openness to trying new things in your intimate life.

questions.text: When it comes to trying new things intimately, I'm generally...
choices: Cautious—I need to feel very safe first

therapeutic.rationale: Exploration openness varies by person. Open-explorers enjoy novelty; selective types are discerning; familiar-pattern types prefer routine; cautious types need high safety. Neither is right or wrong—it's personal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The explorer may feel the cautious partner is closed; the cautious partner may feel pressured. Create safety first, then explore at the pace of the more cautious partner.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared exploration openness makes navigating novelty easier. You'll naturally want similar levels of variety.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about trying new things intimately? What makes you open or hesitant?

questions.text: My comfort zone in intimacy is something I'd like to...

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort zone goals reveal growth orientation. Gentle-expanders want slow growth; keepers are content; active-explorers want more novelty; thinkers want planning first. Partners may have different growth goals.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different comfort zone goals need navigation. The active-explorer may frustrate the keeper; the keeper may bore the explorer. Find growth that feels safe for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort zone goals align your intimate growth. You're aiming for the same trajectory.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your relationship with your comfort zone? Do you want to expand it or protect it?

questions.text: If my partner suggested something outside my comfort zone, I'd want to...
choices: Hear them out with an open mind
Take time to think about it
Understand why it appeals to them
Be honest about my limits without shame

therapeutic.rationale: How we receive stretch requests affects safety. Open-minders create possibility; time-takers process carefully; understanding-seekers connect; limit-setters maintain boundaries. All responses can be healthy.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these responses are healthy. The key is that both partners feel safe making requests and safe declining them.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response approach creates predictability when stretch requests happen.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when asked to try something new? What do you need to feel safe?

questions.text: The balance between routine and novelty I prefer in intimacy is...
choices: Depends on the season of life
Deep connection matters more than variety

therapeutic.rationale: Routine-novelty balance is deeply personal. Routine-preferers find security in patterns; variety-seekers need stimulation; flexible types adapt; connection-focusers prioritize depth over breadth.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The variety-seeker may feel bored; the routine-preferer may feel pressured. Find your sustainable balance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared balance preference makes planning your intimate life easier. You naturally want similar patterns.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What balance of routine and novelty feels right to you? What does that look like?

questions.text: When we try something new and it doesn't work, I'd want us to...
choices: Laugh it off—it's part of exploring

therapeutic.rationale: Failure response affects willingness to explore. Laughers reduce pressure; talkers process; movers-on let it go; appreciators focus on attempt. How you handle awkwardness determines whether you'll try again.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses can complement each other. The key is avoiding shame or blame when experiments don't work.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared failure response creates safety for experimentation. You'll handle awkward moments similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you handle it when something intimate doesn't go well? What response from your partner would help?
